The Story of the Ghost who was a Hunter of Deer
“You were young, with men and women in front,

analyzed: rajanīyehi kāma guṇehi sobhasi  divasam anubhosi kāraṇa
translated: You shone with the delights of sensual pleasures.🔽What did you do in a former life
That you enjoy this during the day?”
“In lovely Rājagaha,
in the delightful Giribbaja,
I was a hunter of deer in the past,
a cruel one with bloody hands.
I was angry with those who did no harm,
and my mind was corrupted towards living beings.
I always roamed around extremely cruel,
delighting in harming others, unrestrained.
A friend of mine, a good friend,
was a faithful lay follower.
Out of compassion for me,
he restrained me again and again.
‘Don’t do bad deeds,
don’t go to a bad destination, my dear.
If you wish for happiness in the next life,

analyzed: virama pāṇa vadhā a sa yamā
translated: refrain from killing living beings, be restrained.’
Having heard his words,
out of love for happiness and compassion,
I didn’t do all that he advised,
long accustomed to evil, lacking understanding.
Then that one of great wisdom,
out of compassion, established me in restraint.
‘If you kill living creatures by day,
Then at night you must be restrained.’
So by day I killed living creatures,
But at night I was restrained and controlled.
At night I went about
And by day I was a wretched creature.

analyzed: tassa kammassa kusalassa  anubhomi rattim amānusi
translated: Because of that wholesome deed,🔽I experience the divine by night;
But by day dogs attack me
And run around on all sides to bite me.
Those who are always devoted
And are constantly engaged in the Dispensation of the One of Good Guidance,
I think they have attained the Deathless alone,
They have attained the state of non-attachment.’
The Story of the Ghost who was a Hunter of Deer is the seventh.
